Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Collaborative Research: I/UCRC for Surveillance Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will support the planning activities for adding two new sites to the existing NSF I/UCRC Center for Surveillance Research (CSR), which is currently composed of Wright State University and Ohio State University (both of which are in Phase 2 effective September 2015). A successful execution of this project will lead to addition of these two new sites to the Center for Surveillance Research, where students and faculty will be working on industrial relevant applied research problems that could generate US Jobs in this unique area, and help with the industrial job placement of students working on Center projects. The fundamental intellectual issues addressed by these new sites will have immediate application in application domains including medical imaging, transportation, and law enforcement.

The core objective of the CSR I/UCRC center has been the development of algorithms for sensor signal and image exploitation, and the development of means to predict the performance and reliability of these algorithms under a variety of operating conditions. Proposed new sites at the University of Kansas and the University of Oklahoma will extend the center's core technologies into weather radar, waveform optimization and spectrum usage, multi-function systems, space-based sensing, and maritime applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this I/UCRC planning grant was to plan and execute a meeting for the purpose of establishing additional university sites with the existing NSF I/UCRC Center for Surveillance Research.The additional academic institutions proposing to join the center are the University of Oklahoma and the University of Kansas.

The planning grant meeting was successfully held on Feb 11-12, 2016. In addition to many faculty representatives from the two academic institutions, representatives from various government labs and potential industry partners attended the meeting. During the meeting the following topics were presented and/or discussed:

  • The purpose and goals of the Center as supported and enhanced by the new university sites were presented to the potential government and industry members;
  • The meeting  introduced and refined an initial research agenda for the new sites;
  • The meeting introduced faculty researchers and research facilities at the University of Oklahoma and the University of Kansas to the potential Center members;
  • The meeting addressed existing center policies and bylaws, and discussed whether any minor changes are appropriate for the new sites; and
  • The meeting provided an opportunity for potential new industry and government members of the center to provide feedback on the academic institutions' proposed research agenda, including how the agendas and capabilities could be modified to mee the research needs of the members.

Industry and government attendees of the meeting received prepared packets containing institutional information, background information on the Center, and abstracts of proposed projects. Further post-meeting followup has communicated the path forward for OU and KU to join the center, and for the industry and government members to participate.
